_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0      EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This document has been prepared to demonstrate how Equity Group Eufaula Division complies with the requirements set forth under EPA's Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68).  

This plan has been developed specifically to address the requirements applicable to the use of anhydrous ammonia at Equity Group Eufaula Division located on Melvin Clark Road, Baker Hill, Alabama. Each of the following sections provides a general overview of the requirements and defines the design attributes, documentation, and actions that are established to comply with those requirements.  In most instances, Equity Group Eufaula Division has already developed measures and systems that provide compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 rules as a result of other regulatory programs and requirements.  This document does not replicate that information but rather provides cross-references to the applicable existing documentation.  In those instances where information was developed specifically to comply with the Part 68 requirements, that information is contained in this document.

1.1.      Corporate Commitment to Safety

Equity Group Eufaula Division is committed in providing to all employees a work environment that is free from recognized health and safety hazards.  Accordingly, our goal is achieving and sustaining a"Zero Accident Tolerance" through communication, information, and training.  We are dedicated to the concept that all employees receive the proper orientation and are provided with the means necessary to ensure the environment remains as safe and healthful as possible.

1.1.1.      It is the policy of Equity Group Eufaula Division to:

1.1.1.1      Provide safe working conditions, proper tools, and personal protective equipment.

1.1.1.2      Comply with all federal, state, and local occupational health, safety, and environmental laws and regulations.

1.1.1.3      Provide and sustain a high level of commitment to ensure all employees have a safe and healthy wor

k environment in which to work.

1.1.1.4      Ensure, through training, and when necessary disciplinary action, that all employees work in a safe manner.

1.1.1.5      Educate and/or train all employees in safe work practices, and ensure that each employee fully understands his or her job, equipment, techniques, and methods to reduce the risk to himself or herself and their co-workers.

1.1.2.      Encourage all employees to "Think Safety", so that safety habits developed and practiced at work carry through to non-work related activities.

1.1.3.      Equity Group Eufaula Division?s aim is to provide a professional service as efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials whereever and whenever prudent.  In this effort our highest priority will be the proactive pursuit of cost-effective process changes that reduce or eliminate the use and/or generation of hazardous toxics at the endpoint of service.  Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, improving controls to handle these substances will be explored and implemented wherever possible.

1.1.4.      Equity Group Eufaula Division has prepared a facility safety policy and procedures program specifically tailored for the facility. In addition, a Process Safety Management Program has also been established and implemented regarding the ammonia refrigeration system process.  It is the responsibility of the designated facility personnel to carry out these programs.

1.1.5.      The first duty of Equity Group Eufaula Division employees is to exercise care in the performance of his/her work tasks to prevent an accident to him/herself, co-workers, the general public or equipment.  Safety-consciousness must take precedence over expedience, and is required as a condition of continued employment of all employees at all levels of the organization.

1.2.      Equity Group Eufaula Division Facility Description

Equity Group Eufaula Division, LLC, is primarily responsible for the slaughter of live poultry and processing of poult

ry products. The facility is located in the rural area of Baker Hill, Alabama and employees approximately 400 personnel.

1.2.1.      The substances regulated under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) that are located on site, in various locations and quantities, are anhydrous ammonia and chlorine gas.

1.2.2.      Anhydrous ammonia is utilized on site for the "Refrigeration System.".  The ammonia is contained in various vessels, piping, condensers and evaporators used throughout the ammonia refrigeration system.  
 
1.2.3.      Chlorine is used at the facility for water treatment and sanitation. The gaseous chlorine is contained in cylinders located by the facility water supply wells.

1.3.     Release Scenarios-Ammonia

1.3.1.      As stipulated in EPA guidelines, 40 CFR Part 68.25(b)(1) the worst-case and alternate case release scenarios involving the anhydrous ammonia process have been calculated. The results of those calculations are held on file at the Equity Group Eufaula facility.
 
1.4.      Emergency Response Program

1.4.1.      Equity Group Eufaula Division is equipped with an emergency information system.  Evacuation plans are placed throughout the facility to inform personnel in an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia, or other emergencies that may be encountered.  There are specific procedures that all employees must follow in the event of release; which can be found in the Equity Group Eufaula Division Emergency Action Plan.  These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop, or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so.

1.4.2.      In addition to evacuation training, plant personnel have received emergency Hazmat training as outlined in OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.120.

1.4.3.      The Baker Hill Volunteer Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discuss emergency response coordination.

2.0      MANAGEMENT

2.1.      Under EPA?s

40 CFR 68.15, the Facility is required to assign a qualified person with overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and documentation of a system to manage the Risk Management program elements.  

2.2.      When responsibility for implementing individual requirements of this RM plan is assigned to persons other than the overall qualified person, the names and positions of those personnel are documented and the lines of authority defined through the Johnsonville  PSM/RM Management System, (refer to Appendix A). 

2.3.      Consistent with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM), Equity Group Eufaula Division Plant Manager, Greg Mills, has overall responsibility for program implementation and management, with support from the Equity Group Eufaula personnel and Equity Group Corporate office.


3.0      WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

3.1.      Under Subpart B of Part 68, subject facilities are required to evaluate the potential hazards that may result in the event of a release of a regulated substance from the facility.  As stipulated in EPA guidelines, 40 CFR Part 68.25(b)(1) the worst-case and alternate case release scenarios involving the anhydrous ammonia process have been calculated. The results of those calculations are held on file at the Equity Group Eufaula facility.

4.0      ACCIDENT HISTORY

No accidental releases from the covered process have occurred resulting deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite or known off-site deaths, injuries, and evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5.0      RMP FILING AND CERTIFICATION

A copy of the electronic submission to the EPA using RMP Submit 2004 is contained in Appendix C of this Risk Management Program.

6.0      PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

6.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.65, the Facility is required to compile written process safety information before conducting any process hazard analysis.  This compilation aids in the identification and understanding of the haza

rds posed by processes involving regulated substances.

6.1.1.      Personal Exposure Limits (PELS) and data regarding physical and chemical characteristics, reactivity, and corrosivity can be found in the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS), located in the Process Safety Information section of the PSM Manual.  Thermal and chemical stability, and compatibility with other chemicals are also addressed in the MSDS.

6.1.2.      A block flow diagram of the process is on file in the engineering department office.

6.1.3.      ThProcess 1 system used at Equity Group Eufaula Division is an enclosed loop mechanical process system that utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a heat exchange media in the processing of the refrigerated food products.  There are no chemical reactions involving ammonia that occur. The principle involved is the ability of a refrigerant, in this case ammonia, to absorb heat as it changes state from a liquid to a gas, and to give up that heat as it changes back to a liquid.  The change in pressure levels required to accomplish this is supplied by the compressors.  The heat is absorbed in the cooling evaporators of various designs, and removed from the system by the condensers.  More detailed and specific descriptions of the process system are provided in the PSM manual.
The Process 2 chemical is chlorine gas which is injected as a controlled gas into the facility water supply for water treatment.

6.1.4.      The safe upper and lower temperatures, pressures, flows and compositions are addressed in the Technical Operating Specifications located in the Operating Procedure section of the PSM Manual.  The consequences of deviating from these safe limits are also addressed in the Operating Procedures as well as the Process Hazard Analysis section of the PSM Manual.

6.1.5.      The Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs) are located in the Refrigeration/Maintenance department office, while the electrical classification, ventilation design, and pressure relief system design ar

e documented in Process Safety Information section of the PSM Manual. 

6.1.6.      The system was designed to meet the applicable sections of ASHRAE, ASTM, ANSI, NEMA, ASTI, and State and County Building Codes.  

6.1.7.      The primary safety system consists of pressure relief valves located on the system's pressure vessels. The relief valves will vent to atmosphere in the event of an overpressure situation within the vessel or associated process components. 

6.1.8.      In addition to the pressure relief valves, there are high-level shutdown devices configured to various pressure vessels within the process, which will shut down compressor operation in the event of an abnormal operating level in the process system vessels.

6.1.9.      The ammonia room and roof top evaporator areas of the facility are equipped with ammonia detection sensors that activate alarms and ventilation fans in the event a pre-determined level of ammonia is released. 

6.1.10.      The ammonia room is also equipped with an emergency shutdown  ?kill? switch located outside the ammonia room exit that will shutdown the entire process system if activated by facility personnel.
      
    
7.0      PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

7.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.67, the facility is required to perform an initial process hazard analysis on processes involving regulated substances.  The analysis is required to identify, evaluate, and control the hazard involved in the process.

7.2.      The hazards of the process are identified in Process Safety Information. Safeguards to control hazards and prevent malfunctions and errors are identified in the Process Hazard Analysis section of the PSM Manual.

7.3.      The consequences of system failures are addressed in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) section of the PSM Manual.

7.4.      The findings and recommendations of the PHA team can be found in the PHA section of the PSM Manual.  The owner/operator's response to the PHA findings, along with the schedule of response action implementation and do

cumentation of the implementation, is also addressed in the PHA section of manual.  

7.5.1.      PHA?s are performed as required by the PSM/RM program, will be revalidated at least once every 5 years.  

7.5.2.      The Equity Group-Eufaula Kill facility?s next PHA revalidation is due no later then May 2009.  

7.5.3.      All PHA documentation is retained for the life of the process.


8.0      OPERATING PROCEDURES

8.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.69, the facility is required to develop and implement written operating procedures for safely conducting activities on processes involving regulated substances.

8.2.      Written procedures, precautions, and parameters for the safe operation, shutdown, and maintenance of the system are addressed in the Operating Procedures section of the PSM Manual. 

8.3.      Procedures for start-up, temporary operations, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown are included in the Operating Procedures Section.

8.4.      Operating limits, consequences of deviation, and steps required to correct or avoid deviation are addressed in the Operating Procedures and the PHA sections of the manual.


9.0      TRAINING

9.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.71, the facility is required to provide training to employees operating processes involving regulated substances.

9.2.      All employees will received initial training as described in Section of the PSM Manual, and will be followed by refresher training a minimum of once every three years.  Employees will receive continual on the-job training regarding understanding hazards, operating procedures, maintenance, and inspection.  

9.2.1.      Sign-in sheets, verification of understanding and documentation of the training for each employee are located in the Refrigeration/Maintenance department office files. 

10.0      MECHANICAL INTEGRITY/MAINTENANCE

10.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.73, the facility is required to establish and implement written procedures to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment, to provide training to employees regard

ing these procedures, and to provide for testing and inspection of process equipment.

10.2.      Procedures for testing, inspection and preventative maintenance of the process equipment are included in the Mechanical Integrity section of the PSM Manual.  

10.3.      Documentation of maintenance activities is maintained on file within the   facility?s computerized maintenance management system, (CMMS).  

11.0      MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

11.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.75, the facility is required to establish and implement written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. 

11.2.      Written procedures to manage changes and requirements for training personnel when changes occur, or when Standard Operating Procedures or Standard Maintenance Procedures are updated, are located in the Management of Change section of the PSM Manual.

12.0      COMPLIANCE AUDITS

12.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.79, the facility is required to certify that the procedures and practices developed under this standard have been evaluated at least every 3 years and that they are adequate and are being followed. 
12.2.      An audit to evaluate facility compliance within the requirements of this program will be completed every 3 years.  

12.3.      Documentation of findings, responses, and corrective actions resulting from the completion of the PSM audit checklist shall be added into the PSM Manual. 

12.4.      The two most recent audit reports will be maintained on file in the PSM Manual.

13.0      INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

13.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.81, the facility is required to investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. 

13.2.      Within 48 hours of each incident that results in, or could have resulted in, a "catastrophic release" of ammonia, an investigation shall be initiated into the incident in accordance with the Emergency Action Plan. 

13.3.      An investigation report shall document the date a

nd time of the incident, along with a description of the incident with its contributing factors, and recommendations to avoid future incidents.  Incident Investigation guidelines and reports can be found in the Incident Investigation section of the PSM manual.

13.4.      Copies of completed investigation reports will be maintained for a period of 5 years.

14.0      EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

14.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.83, the facility is required to develop a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation. 

14.2.      A written plan of action for employee participation in Process Hazard Analysis, Management of Change, and training is included in the Employee Participation section of the PSM Manual. 

14.3.      Access to documents is also addressed in the Employee Participation section of the PSM Manual.


15.0     HOT WORK PERMITS

15.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.85, the facility is required to issue hot work permits for hot work conducted on or near a covered process. 

15.2.      Hot work permits shall be issued in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.252(a), and as described in the PSM Standard 1910.119(k).

16.0      CONTRACTOR PROGRAM

16.1.      Responsibilities of the facility and of contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovations, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process are specified under 40 CFR 68.87. This section does not apply to contractors providing incidental services that do not influence process safety, such as janitorial work or food services.

16.2.      Equity Group Eufaula Division personnel shall evaluate the safety performance and safety programs of contractors during the selection process, in accordance with guidelines in the PSM Manual. 

16.3.      Equity Group Eufaula Division shall provide hazard information and emergency response procedures to all contractors prior to their entering the Facility to commence work.

16.4.      Contractors shall receive un-announced performance evaluations regarding the fulfillment of t

heir obligations, including:

16.4.1.      Each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job.

16.4.2.      Each contract employee is instructed in the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to his/her job and the process, and the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.

16.5.      The contractor has documented that each contract employee has received and understood the required training.  Documentation to be maintained by the contractor shall include the employee's name, date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

16.6.      Each contract employee follows applicable facility safe work practices.

16.7.      The contractor will notify Equity Group Eufaula personnel of any unique hazards presented by the contractor's work or any hazards found.

17.0      EMERGENCY RESPONSE / ACTION PROGRAM

17.1.      Under 40 CFR 68.95, the facility is required to develop and implement an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.

17.2.      Equity Group Eufaula employees have received training as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.38.  Their objective is to recognize and to initiate the facility?s emergency action plan in the event that the emergency situation is beyond the facility?s capacity. Employees will report the release of hazardous/toxic substances set forth by the governing regulations, rules, and policies.

17.3.      Procedures for notifying the local emergency response agencies of accidental releases are detailed in the facility?s Emergency Action Plan.

17.4.      Documentation of emergency medical procedures to treat accidental human exposures is included in the Emergency Action Plan as well as the Process Safety Information and Operating Procedure sections of the PSM Manual.
